item.title: Justin Smoak and BABIP Trends
item.description: The podcast I listen to said something like, “I bet Justin Smoak must have one of the lowest BABIPs of anyone to this point in his career,” and I thought it might be a good chance to explore this nebulous BABIP a little. library(Lahman) library(dplyr) ## ## Attaching package: 'dplyr' ## The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': ## ## filter, lag ## The following objects are masked from 'package:base': ## ## intersect, setdiff, setequal, union library(ggplot2) library(hrbrthemes) BABIP is calculated as balls in play (hits minus home runs) divided by total at bats that caused these balls in play (at bats minus strikeouts minus home runs plus sacrifice flies).
